I believe I'll now produce final answer.</think>We will show that if kₙ is a positive integer whose representation in base (n + 1) consists of exactly two digits, then necessarily

  kₙ = n(n + 1).

To explain, recall that any two‐digit number in base (n + 1) has the form

  a·(n + 1) + b  with  1 ≤ a ≤ n and 0 ≤ b ≤ n.

In other words, its value is at least
  1·(n + 1) = n + 1,
and at most
  n·(n + 1) + n = n² + 2n.
Thus every two‐digit number in base (n + 1) lies between n + 1 and n² + 2n.

Now, suppose we want a sequence {kₙ} so that for each natural number n the “base–(n+1)” representation of kₙ has exactly two digits. One natural choice is to “use up” as much room as possible while keeping the form a·(n + 1) + b in mind. In fact, if we choose

  kₙ = n(n + 1),
then when we divide by (n + 1) we get
  kₙ ÷ (n + 1) = [n(n + 1)]⁄(n + 1) = n,
with remainder 0. That is, in base (n + 1) the number kₙ is written as “n0” (the digit n followed by a 0). Since in base (n + 1) the allowed digits are 0, 1, 2, …, n, this representation is valid and consists of exactly two digits.

Let’s check the first few values:
 • For n = 1: k₁ = 1·2 = 2. In base 2 the number 2 is written as “10”.
 • For n = 2: k₂ = 2·3 = 6. In base 3, 6 = 2×3 + 0, so it is “20” in base 3.
 • For n = 3: k₃ = 3·4 = 12. In base 4, 12 = 3×4 + 0, i.e. “30” in base 4.
 • For n = 4: k₄ = 4·5 = 20. In base 5, 20 = 4×5 + 0, so it is “40” in base 5.

In each case the representation has exactly two digits.

Thus one acceptable answer is:

 For every natural number n, let
  kₙ = n(n + 1).
Then when written in base (n + 1) we have kₙ = (n)(0)₍ₙ₊₁₎ (i.e. “n0”), which is a two‐digit number.

This answer is unique if one wishes the sequence to “use up” as much of the allowable range as possible while keeping the representation exactly two digits long.
